sunchao commented on issue #4174: ARROW-5189: [Rust] [Parquet] Format / display individual fields within a parquet row
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4174#issuecomment-485005717
 
 
   Yes, you'd need to know the schema before you can access any field from the row. However this is expected if the client wants to do any meaningful processing on an individual column. 
   
   Let me know if the above solution can satisfy your requirement. Right now I'm not seeing a strong reason to add this new feature.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

FabioBatSilva commented on issue #4174: ARROW-5189: [Rust] [Parquet] Format / display individual fields within a parquet row
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4174#issuecomment-485024962
 
 
   @sunchao  Did some tests here and formatting whit `get_xxx ` is not aways possible.. 
   Since you are formatting the underlining data with a field not the field it self..
   
   While `Field` implements `Display` 
   `Map` and other underlying data structures might not..
   
   
   ```
   println!("map : {}", row.get_map(i).unwrap());
        ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ `record::api::Map` cannot be formatted with the default formatter
   ```
   
   
   The problem i think this solves is when you don't know or don't care about the schema.
   In my case i'm reading arbitrary parquet files and need to get a string representation for some columns within a row..
   
   ```rust
   for i in 0..row.len() {
       println!("row[{}] : {}", i, row.fmt(i).unwrap());
   }
   ```
   
   To do the same thing using `get_xxx` first you need to lookup the type in the schema and have a different branch for each type invoking get_xxx and then maybe format it if the underlining data implements `Display`.
   
   ```rust
   for i in 0..row.len() {
       look_up_type(schema, i) {
           PhysicalType::INT32 => println!("row[{}] : {}", i, row.get_int(i).unwrap()),
           PhysicalType::BYTE_ARRAY => println!("row[{}] : {}", i, row.get_string(i).unwrap()),
           // ...
           _ => panic!("Unsupported type")
       }
   }
   ```
   
   Maybe this is just specific to what i'm trying to do but if fells like there should be a simpler way to format a single column.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

     fn get_map(&self, i: usize) -> Result<&Map>;
 }
 
+/// Trait for formating fields within a Row.
+pub trait RowFormatter {
 
 Review comment:
   Should we export this to `mod.rs`?

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4174#discussion_r277113778
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/parquet/src/record/api.rs
 ##########
 @@ -102,6 +107,16 @@ macro_rules! row_complex_accessor {
   }
 }
 
+impl RowFormatter for Row {
+    /// Get Display reference for a given field.
+    fn fmt(&self, i: usize) -> Result<&fmt::Display> {
 
 Review comment:
   Instead of returning `Result`, can we just return `&fmt::Display`? I think it is OK to panic here as people should know the number of fields from the `Row` (via `len()`) and pass proper `i` into the method. We can avoid many `unwrap`s in this way.

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description:
The current api for a *parquet::record::Row*  doesn't provide a way to get a string representation of individual column within a Row.

All *Field* s in a row already implement *{{fmt::Display}}* but there is now way to format individual fields since the *Row#fields* is not exposed by the api.

Formatting individual fields seems like a common problem,
 I belie having this as part of the *parquet::record::Row* api would would be helpful to anyone peking into values within a row..
fields.summary: [Rust] [Parquet] Format individual fields within a parquet row
